snippet: Most of the presumptive presidential candidates have not plunged into Washington’s debate over the Senate Intelligence Committee’s withering report on the C.I.A.’s brutal interrogation tactics.
abstract: Most presumptive 2016 presidential candidates have declined to weigh in on Senate Intelligence Committee’s withering report on CIA's brutal interrogation tactics, illustrating delicate politics of national security; few want to be seen as defending torture, particularly in aftermath of graphic techniques depicted in panel’s findings, and yet, at same time, they do not want to be seen as soft on terrorism.

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and MICHAEL BARBARO
byline.contributor: Sheryl Gay Stolberg reported from Washington, and Michael Barbaro from New York. Reporting was contributed by Jonathan Martin, Ashley Parker, Amy Chozick, Jeremy W. Peters and Trip Gabriel.

lead_paragraph: Most of the presumptive presidential candidates have not plunged into Washington’s debate over the Senate Intelligence Committee’s withering report on the C.I.A.’s brutal interrogation tactics.

headline.main: Torture Report Puts Presidential Hopefuls in Quiet Mode
headline.print_headline: Torture Report Puts Politicians in Quiet Mode
